bibl.title: Gin Kato v. State of Washington. Memorandum of Authorities
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: The District Court of the United States, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: In the United States District Court of the Western District of Washington, Northern Division.
In the Matter of the Petition of GIN KATO for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.

A careful consideration of the Immigration Statute of 1917, Section 19, will disclose that the draftsman of the statute started out with a general limitation of five years, and wherever he desired to dispense with any limitation of five years, and wherever he desired to dispense with any limitation he was careful to use the words "at any time". In the clause of the Section which deals with petitioner the words "at any time" do not appear. The effect of this is to bring this particular charge under the general limitation of five years.

The statute in this case invades the treaty rights of petitioner. By the treaty between Japan and the United States, ratified March 21, 1895, and proclaimed the same day, the subjects of Japan are given in the United States th same rights of residence and travel,possession of goods and effects etc. as citizens of the United States. The right of residence undoubtedly gives the right to earn a living by any lawful means. The occupation of petitioner in the place complained of by the Government would be lawful in the case of a citizen. While it may be competent for Congress to override a treaty by limitation it is not the presumptions are to the contrary.
As to invasion of treaty rights see Ah Chung, 2 Fed.733.
Yick Wo vs. Hopkins, 118 U.S. 356,30 L.Ed. 220.
Wong Wing vs. U.S.163 U.S.228, 41 La.Ed.140.
